Eep.Action: Provides a clear and insightful narration about her family and their survival, showing understanding of their harsh environment.
Describes the family as constantly scared and struggling to find food, implying difficulty adapting or thriving.
Acknowledges her personal struggle to survive her family dynamics, indicating self-awareness.
Relies heavily on her father's strength and rule-following, which may signify lack of independent confidence or initiative.
Scares a pack of hostile liyotes away from Grug, protecting him.
Emerges before the given signal, acting independently and disregarding rules.
Expresses dissatisfaction with the family's confinement, showing openness and sincerity about feelings.
Scares a pack of nearby Liyotes away, protecting Grug.
Bursts out of the cave before the agreed signal, ignoring Grug's instructions.
Spreads out on an overhanging rock and basks in the sun, appearing relaxed and confident.
Expresses dissatisfaction about staying in the cave for days, indicating awareness and desire for change.
Volunteers eagerly to be first to take action during the hunt (hand shoots up quickly).
Calls 'Heads' during the flip, engaging actively in the game.
Moves in on the bird to retrieve the egg alongside Sandy and Ugga.
Launches herself to stop the Liyote and retrieves the stolen egg.
Thanks Gran after recovering the egg.
Warns Grug by saying 'Heads Up!' when he is about to catch the egg.
Launches from cover and runs after the Liyote with the stolen egg, cutting him off and causing him to slam into a cactus, then leaps to catch the egg mid-air.
Loses footing when swarmed by Jackrobats and has to throw the egg to Grug.
Hangs off the edge of the Girelephant's tusk, actively participating in slowing down the animal to protect the family.
Hangs off the edge of one of the Girelephant's tusks to help slow it down during a chase.
Actively participates in maneuvering the Girelephant to fend off the Bearowl with Grug.
Clings to the side of the rock face to catch sunlight, seeming to enjoy a moment alone without disrupting others.
Begins to climb down when called but becomes curious and climbs higher instead, potentially ignoring Grug’s concern.
Clings confidently to the sheer rock face outside the cave, raising her hand to catch sun before descending carefully.
Hears a distant sound and chooses to climb higher out of curiosity instead of descending immediately.
Disobeys Grug's implied instruction to come down and instead ventures higher, potentially risking safety and disobeying authority.
Jumps down quickly when warned by Grug, showing responsiveness and trust.
Climbs up despite danger, possibly disregarding others' safety.
Answers Grug's questioning with annoyance and evasiveness.
Questions the purpose of survival out loud, revealing sincere vulnerability.
Continues to climb despite father's warnings and the presence of danger.
Jumps down and darts into the cave at the right moment after the bear owl is stunned.
Can't clearly explain her motives or reasoning for climbing up; answers vaguely and annoyingly.
Questions the purpose of their survival and existence, showing reflective thinking.
Hits Grug with a pebble from her ledge when he challenges her need for space.
Remains silent and distant when Grug tries to engage her with the story, not immediately joining the group.
Throws a pebble at Grug's head to get his attention, showing assertiveness and a form of communication despite non-verbal means.
Refuses to come down or engage when called, ignoring direct requests and social expectations.
Has her own ledge to work through things, indicating some level of emotional or mental self-management and independence.
Does not join the family gathering to hear the story when prompted, opting to stay away from the group activity.
Does not join the family pile for warmth and comfort, stays apart on her own ledge.
Tosses restlessly on her ledge while family sleeps peacefully together, indicating possible alienation or difference from group.
Tosses restlessly on her ledge while family sleeps, indicating unease with routine and fear.
Does not join the family huddling together for safety despite dangers outside.
Carefully creeps around her sleeping family to explore outside without waking them.
Bravely pushes the heavy rock door to sneak out, showing care not to disturb her family.
Chases the mysterious light out of curiosity and excitement, demonstrating openness and a playful spirit.
Throws a rock at the shadow of the tusked creature when scared.
Leaps back in shock when she sees Guy, accidentally dropping a rock on his foot.
Moves swiftly to silence Guy, pounces on him and twists his head to stop him from shouting, causing him to suffocate.
Throws a rock at the shadow and climbs the stone wall with unexpected speed, causing the Creature to run away.
Cautiously approaches the torch, showing awareness and curiosity.
Smells the Creature behind her, reacts with determination, and physically overpowers the Creature by throwing and flipping it over her shoulder.
Jumps back and grabs a rock, prepared to defend herself by potentially hitting the Creature.
Gasps in shock upon seeing the Creature has human hands, showing momentary surprise.
Leaps back, accidentally drops the rock on Guy's foot, causing him pain.
Moves swiftly to silence Guy by suffocating him, showing quick thinking but potentially risky and aggressive behavior.
Pounces on Guy and twists his head to silence him.
Lifts Guy with one hand after tossing boulder aside.
Opens Guy's mouth, pokes and sniffs him curiously despite his protests.
Drops Guy on his head, jams her foot over his mouth, and kicks him after he bites her foot.
Fights Guy with significant aggression to keep quiet and avoid being caught.
Blocks Guy from taking the fire, claiming it as hers, showing possessiveness but also attachment to the flame.
Allows Guy to revive the fire after seeing his need and fear of darkness, indicating empathy and tolerance.
Scoots closer to Guy, showing comfort and a friendly inclination towards him.
Expresses fascination and excitement about fire and Guy's power, showing sincere curiosity and openness.
Grabs Guy tightly by the hair and forces him to 'make' fire, an aggressive and demanding action.
Squeezes Guy like a tube of toothpaste, causing physical harm and displaying impatience and lack of gentleness.
Shows concern for Guy by checking if he is dead and asking for his fire.
Refuses to leave with Guy immediately, staying put like an anchor despite danger.
Expresses honest confusion and curiosity by asking about pants and who Guy is.
Test-blows the shell and giggles, showing appreciation and lightheartedness.
Says thank you to Guy after receiving the shell.
Tries to explain herself to Grug, indicating openness and willingness to communicate.
Whispers to Grug that he never lets her talk, expressing frustration but in a non-hostile way.
Kicks a rock furiously and nearly hits Grug, showing anger and impulsiveness.
Test-blows the shell and reacts with delight, showing curiosity and quick engagement with a new object.
Leaves on her own to follow Guy, demonstrating initiative but possibly impulsiveness.
Bumps into Grug immediately after Guy disappears, showing a lack of attention to surroundings.
Whispers to Grug that he never lets her talk, implying frustration and difficulty in communication but also standing up for herself.
Tries to calmly explain that the 'new' thing isn't bad and that the boy warthog was nice despite her family's fear.
Elbows Thunk when he mocks her, showing some irritation but not hostility.
Attempts to call the boy with the shell despite her family's defensive reaction.
Responds with incredulity and anger towards the Croods after they destroy her shell and reject the new boy.
Finds something new and tries to share it excitedly with her family despite their fear.
Squeezes her way out from the defensive circle to speak up and explain the situation.
Mistakes a boy for a warthog initially, showing a misjudgment.
Blows into the shell to summon the boy despite warnings, showing determination but poor judgment of risk.
Expresses frustration and disbelief when her actions are rejected or met with fear, indicating emotional response but resolving to communicate.
Pelts Thunk with a rock.
Throws a tantrum, slams a rock on the ground breaking it.
Throws a tantrum and slams a rock on the ground causing a larger geological event.
Predicts the ground shaking and collapse, demonstrating foresight.
Pelts Thunk with a rock playfully/dangerously.
Encourages the Croods to explore the new world and shares her excitement openly with the group.
Steps forward with hope and enthusiasm despite Grug's resistance and the danger posed by the Bear Owl.
Steps forward to see the new world and suggests they should go there.
Acts despite Grug's objections and runs toward the new world with the family.
Follows Grug's lead without hesitation when they need to find a cave and move carefully.
Takes in the wonders of the strange forest calmly while the group moves cautiously.
Does not intervene or react impulsively when surrounded by Punch Monkeys; remains observant.
Encourages and advises Grug during the fight, telling him to stop running into the Punch Monkeys' fists.
Participates actively and confidently in the fight and chase sequences showing awareness and quick reaction.
Breaks a horn from a skull and blows on it loud and long to call for help.
Spies a skull, sprints for it, breaks a horn, and blows on it loud and long to signal for help.
Stands alone in the clearing, calling out to Guy, showing trust and seeking help.
Does not resist or retaliate when Guy knocks the horn out of her hand to stop the noise.
Stays close to Guy when the Croods threat display begins, indicating trust and solidarity.
Calls out to Guy despite the danger from circling birds.
Holds the horn and attempts to make noise to attract attention.
Lets Guy knock the horn out of her hand instead of reacting defensively.
Seems confused or hesitant when Guy explains the Croods are 'cavemen'.
Slaps the knife away to protect her family, admits they are her family with embarrassment.
Proudly credits Guy with making fire, showing respect and appreciation.
Expresses concern when Guy gets hurt, indicating care and empathy.
Slaps away Guy's knife to protect her family, showing quick protective instincts and confidence.
Correctly identifies 'fire' when others do not understand, showing knowledge and intelligence.
Explains that fire doesn’t come out of Guy but doesn’t elaborate further, showing partial understanding but some lack of clarity.
Shows embarrassment when confronting the knife situation, indicating some emotional reaction that might impact decisiveness.
Comments 'Great, now he's broken' after Guy falls, showing awareness but some passivity rather than immediate problem-solving.
Expresses determination to protect Guy from her father despite danger.
Says 'They're not so scary once you get to know them.'
Pounces on Guy like a tiger.
Says 'They're not so scary once you get to know them.' showing open-mindedness and confidence.
Gets hit by the speeding corn along with Guy without avoiding it.
Quickly notices Guy is missing and actively looks for him, pouncing on him like a tiger.
Pounces on Guy, insists on not letting him go for safety reasons.
Brightly tells Guy he doesn't have a mission anymore, dismissing his feelings.
Pounces on Guy and physically restrains him to prevent him from leaving, showing determination and quick action.
Articulates concerns about finding a cave before sunset, showing some foresight and practical thinking.
Brightly declares that Guy no longer has his mission or reason to live, indicating confidence and assertiveness.
Accepts Grug's decision to keep Guy with the family, showing adaptability.
Seemingly accepts Grug's opinion about the mountain being too far without strong objection, which could suggest lack of strategic pushback or vision.
Reassures Sandy when Belt antagonizes her by saying 'No no, it's okay Sandy. That's just a belt.'
Raises an eyebrow when Grug talks about the family becoming closer on the trip.
Questions Guy about the mountain to verify information (Have you been there?).
Calms Sandy by reassuring her that Belt is just a belt.
Raises one eyebrow at Grug's suggestion, indicating skepticism or critical thinking.
Says 'Isn't this fun? We're taking our first trip together' amid family chaos.
Warns Thunk 'Stop shoving, or I will pull out your tongue!'
Expresses enthusiasm about the family trip despite chaos around her.
Warns Thunk to stop shoving or she will pull out his tongue, showing confidence and assertiveness.
Asks repeatedly and insistently to carry him, showing eagerness and persistence to help or be involved.
Repeatedly asks to take a turn carrying an important burden despite being refused, showing persistence and confidence.
Shows eagerness to join the hunt, displays hunting face even when grounded.
Agitated and tense watching others hunt but does not act impulsively or recklessly in this scene.
Chases Guy and pins him down when he tries to leave, showing concern and engagement.
Chases Guy and pins him down to question his behavior instead of letting him leave.
Offers bugs for dinner when Guy is hungry, despite it being unappealing.
Eagerly participates and follows Guy's instructions to set the trap, showing cooperation.
Asks how long Guy has been alone, showing curiosity and possible empathy.
Leaps up and grabs the leaning top of the tree to bend it down as part of setting a snare trap with Guy.
Asks Guy what the trap is and how it works, showing curiosity and willingness to learn.
Accepts that her dinner is bugs without complaint, indicating a lack of assertiveness for better options.
Having fun working the puppet with Guy, showing playful engagement and cooperation.
Stands boldly in front of the Turkey Fish to protect Guy, displaying bravery and protective instincts.
Leaps the snare and pushes Grug down to prevent him from springing the trap, showing quick thinking but also putting her father at risk.
Having fun confidently working the puppet and coordinating with Guy despite getting tangled up.
Boldly stands in front of the Turkey Fish to protect Guy despite the danger.
Leaps over the snare to push Grug down, preventing him from being caught and allowing the trap to work successfully.
Sits next to captive Guy and politely shares the meal, showing acceptance and friendliness despite the tense situation.
Inquires about the concept of 'leftovers' with genuine curiosity, indicating openness and trust in conversation.
Learns about 'left-overs' and openly admits they never have that much food.
Is entranced by Guy's vision of tomorrow and locks eyes with him, showing openness and curiosity.
Does not intervene when Guy is at risk of slipping off the log hanging over a cliff.
Winks and offers to handle the situation with Guy, showing confidence and approachability.
Falls back behind Thunk, putting her sibling between herself and her dad, showing protective/friendly behavior.
Tricks Thunk by saying he has a spider on his face, then smashes him, knocking him into Grug and causing chaos.
Shrugs and says 'Oops' after causing trouble, indicating lack of apology or remorse.
Winks confidently and says 'Leave this to me.'
Falls back behind Thunk to put a barrier between herself and her dad, showing protective or tactical thinking.
Tricks Thunk by telling him he has a spider on his face, then hits him in the face causing chaos and the log to fly, resulting in Guy being loose.
Shrugs and says 'Oops' after causing unintended consequences, demonstrating lack of responsibility or care.
Feels pity for Guy when he struggles to leave the Croods.
Expresses excitement and joy about new shoes, saying 'I love them!'
Slips and falls into Guy's arms and thanks him sincerely for catching her
Expresses excitement and confidence about the new 'shoes' and quickly adapts to wearing them.
Slips and falls into Guy's arms while trying the new footwear, showing some clumsiness.
Notices and compliments Ugga's shoes, expressing delight ('Oh wow. I love those!')
Accepts Guy's help to avoid falling while crossing the canyon
Wears shoes and runs faster, showing adaptation and use of new tools.
Receives help from Guy to avoid falling while traveling on stilts across a canyon.
Asks Guy a question about how the tiger flew, showing curiosity and engagement.
Allows Guy to pull her under the umbrella to be close to him during the rain
Points at her own reflection despite her father's warning
Responds to Grug with mild teasing, 'Oh dad, you say that about everything'
Attempts to jump into the water despite danger
Points at her own reflection confidently, despite her father's warning about danger.
Responds to her father's caution by dismissing it lightly ('Oh dad, you say that about everything.').
Attempts to jump into potentially dangerous water despite warnings, needing to be stopped by Guy.
Tentatively hops into the water and begins to swim with Guy's support.
Climbs on Guy's shoulders playfully while swimming.
Tentatively hops in the water and begins to swim after being shown by Guy, supported and learning the motion confidently.
Encourages her father by saying 'We can do it, dad.' when he is hesitant about splitting up.
Affirms confidence in splitting up to tackle the maze, telling her dad 'We can do it, dad.'
Picks up a flower and puts it in her hair, then playfully begins hunting for Guy
Picks up a flower, puts it in her hair, and playfully begins hunting for Guy.
Playfully hunts for Guy after finding flowers dropped on her path.
Surprises Guy and Belt in their hideaway and gently admonishes Guy by saying 'You dropped these.'
Shares a shy, tender moment with Guy before disappearing.
Playfully hunts for Guy by following dropped flowers, surprises Guy and Belt in their hideaway confidently.
Shyly vanishes after sharing a moment with Guy, showing some hesitation or lack of assertiveness.
Approaches Guy at a moment of concern, indicating willingness to stay close and share experience.
Comes to Guy's side when fires and smoke are seen on the horizon, indicating awareness and readiness.
Says 'Tomorrow' in response to Guy's statement about where they will be safe, showing understanding and engagement.
Expresses tears in her eyes when hearing about danger, shows emotional openness.
Determines to go with Guy, invites Grug to come with them.
Decides to go with Guy despite family tensions, showing initiative and willingness to take action.
Has tears in her eyes, indicating emotional vulnerability but also determination.
Calls out to her father when he disappears, alerting others and showing awareness of the situation.
Rejects moving into another cave despite the danger, indicating independent thinking and a desire for change.
Tells Grug he has to stop worrying for all of them, showing concern for his well-being and wanting him to be less burdened.
Refuses to go into the cave despite Grug's orders, showing independent thinking and courage.
Tells Grug he has to stop worrying about others, indicating emotional intelligence and confidence.
Challenges Grug's insistence on following old rules and advocates for new ways to live, showing concern for the group's well-being.
Directly confronts Grug and insists they follow Guy in front of everyone, which could be seen as bold but sincere for the group's survival.
Challenges the validity of old rules and asserts that following Guy is necessary for survival.
Declares that the family would be dead if they continued to follow Grug's old ways.
Expresses a strong desire to fix everything with Grug before leaving, showing sincerity and emotional openness.
Accepts and likes Grug's idea of a 'Hug,' engaging in a warm moment of connection.
Admits fear honestly to her dad, showing vulnerability and trust.
Refuses to move forward because she feels she needs to fix everything and doesn't have time, expressing determination and self-awareness.
Expresses fear openly when the ground begins to shake and break apart.
Blows shell alarm multiple times to signal family is in trouble.
Blows her shell horn alone at the edge of the cliff, appears somber.
Shares a quiet, emotional moment with Gran who comforts her.
Breaks into tears, is happily surprised by family's support, runs to hug Grug ferociously and expresses love sincerely.
Blows her shell horn confidently and persistently despite others' reactions, showing determination and control.
Breaks into tears, showing emotional vulnerability but no indication of loss of control or incompetence.
Hugging Grug ferociously, nearly knocking him down, indicating emotional expressiveness but slight lack of physical control.
Points out the amazing view to the family, prompting consideration of moving forward.
Fixes her hair calmly while the family prepares for a photo, showing composure and self-assurance.
Flips out of the trees and blows her horn to call Guy and the BearOwl for a ride.
States that because of her dad, anyone can change.
Blows her horn to call Guy and the BearOwl for a ride, facilitating movement and coordination.
Expresses confidence in changing the rules that kept them in the dark, showing insight and vision.
Rides the BearOwl confidently alongside Guy, demonstrating skill and composure.
